docBody.head: BIRTH CONTROL, 1940
docBody.p: With the outbreak of the present World War, the continued drive of the totalitarian nations for increased population and the subjugation of the democracies where birth control programs had been in progress, not only have activities ceased in large part in these countries but with the rigid censorship, no news on what is transpiring has filtered through.

The forced migration of millions of people in Central Europe, the starvation of millions more, the separation of families with great bodies of troops either in movement or at the various fronts and away from home, have all acted as a form of birth control. The birth rate always drops during war and remains low for some time after it.

The malnutrition extending over large areas in Europe will affect fertility adversely during and after the war. With these factors will come the fear of depopulation which manifested itself before the war, and will probably be intensified later. It is hoped that there will also follow increased recognition of the need for intelligent and honest efforts to solve the problems of population pressure, especially those dealing with population distribution in relation to national resources. Without such solution, a lasting peace can never be achieved for these causes are basic reasons for aggression.

Emphasis in the United States birth control movement has been on the need for expanding birth control services as a means of strengthening the physical, and economic well-being of the nation as it plans for national defense.

Where reports have come through from abroad, there is evidence of continued activity and expansion of birth control facilities in countries not affected directly by the war, and the recognition of birth control as a public health measure has been growing in several of the Latin-American countries and the West Indies.

item.p: AUSTRALIA Birth Control clinics continued to operate in Australia, but mothers in the low income group are given a maternity bonus of $20 on the birth of each child and in New South Wales a small weekly payment for each child after the first.

CUBA In Havana, films dealing with the "Technique of Contraception" have been widely presented to the medical profession and the leading medical associations. There is particular interest in the birth control program of its neighboring Island, Puerto Rico, where efforts to solve similar problems of overpopulation have been underway for several years.

ENGLAND Activities of the Family Planning Association continued in Great Britain up to the outbreak of the war. Birth control clinics still functioned, and while formal reports from them were few and irregular, visitors from England reported increasing attendance, particularly among younger women, attempting to carry on under conditions of physical uncertainty, economic insecurity, and family disruption. The clinic of Dr. Marie Stopes, the first established in London, was bombed in an air raid in October, 1940, and partly demolished. The NEW GENERATION and the BIRTH CONTROL NEWS continued to present the health and welfare arguments for planned parenthood.

FRANCE The new code which went into effect late in 1939, not only provided new and drastic regulations against abortion, but prohibited the advertising of contraception. Because of censorship of everything published, including even a discussion of contraception, LA GRANDE REFORME, the French Neo-Malthusian Journal, edited by Eugene Humbert, suspended publication late in the year.

Following the conquest of France, Jean Ibarnegaray, Minister of Youth in the Vichy Government, announced a new policy to stimulate the birth rate. The young women of France will be educated for one purpose only! "To return to their traditional purpose of life--being in their homes and living only to raise strong useful men." Fathers of families will be given preference over bachelors in both public and private employment and will be paid in proportion to the size of their families.

GERMANY Germany continued an uncompromising opposition to any form of birth control. In December 1939, a new population policy was officially announced. All soldiers going to the front are expected to leave children or prospective children behind them. "It can become an exalted task even outside of wedlock," says Herr Himmler, "for German women and girls of good blood to become--not frivolously, but imbued with deepest moral concern--mothers of children begotten by soldiers moving to the front, without knowing whether they will return or die for the Fatherland".

Since the outbreak of the present war, censorship in Germany has resulted in a complete cessation of all statistical material on population. It is impossible, therefore, to ascertain whether the new policy has resulted in a higher birth rate in Germany.

HOLLAND New birth control clinics were opened in Amsterdam and Enschede, both in industrial sections where many factory workers live. This progress took place prior to the invasion of Holland. Since then, no news has been received.

INDIA The All-India Women's Conference, which met in Allahabad in January 1940, adopted a new resolution on family planning which urged that women medical officers in municipal and government hospitals, dispensaries and health centers advise married women on child spacing, and that the technique of contraception be taught these officers.

The National Planning Commission appointed by the National Congress passed a Resolution that family planning and limitation of children are essentials in the interest of national economy, and urged the state to adopt a policy encouraging the establishment of birth control clinics and other necessary measures to encourage the spread of cheap and safe methods of birth control.

JAPAN Japan's official pressure for a higher birth rate during the war has resulted in an increase in the rate of infant mortality. Coupled with the demand for an increase in population, as a patriotic duty during the war, suppression of birth control clinics and discussion of birth control continues.

NEW ZEALAND The Sex Hygiene and Birth Regulation Society of New Zealand dissolved during the year to re-form as The Family Planning Association, affiliated with the British organization. A deputation of Workers from the Association in conference with the Ministry of Health requested that contraceptive advice be given by physicians when necessary, at State Maternity Hospitals.

PUERTO RICO With the legality of contraceptive advice, under medical direction, established in Puerto Rico by legal decision in 1939, clinic services have been established under the supervision of the Puerto Rico Board of Health. The Associacion pro Salud Maternal e Infantil de Puerto Rico, under the medical direction of Dr. J. S. Beleval, continued its educational and research efforts to determine the type of contraceptive best adapted for use on the Island. Public interest in the medical and public health aspects of birth control were stimulated by a visit from Mrs. Sanger in 1940, and the medical films on contraception are being widely shown among scientific and medical groups.

SWEDEN The new population measures instituted in Sweden which went into effect January 1, 1938, based on the principle that voluntary parenthood and a positive population policy must be brought together, are now in their second year. This policy emphasizes that only children welcome to their parents are wanted by the nation; but also recognizes that certain social conditions must be re-arranged that more children can be welcomed. Birth control services have been widely extended to reach all groups of society, but to reduce the economic motive for extreme family regulation, a series of measures involving, not cash premiums to parents, but health and environmental services benefiting the children themselves have been put into effect. Already skilled laborers and artisans in Swedish cities are having more children than the unskilled. It is to be hoped that the war will not destroy Sweden's interesting and historic experiment.

CLINICS The growth of birth control centers in the United States continued. On November 1, 1940 these totalled 589, of which 106 were in hospitals, 178 in Health Departments, and 305 in other quarters, largely extramural. Of these centers, 206 were supported wholly or in part by public funds.

MEDICAL TEACHING OF CONTRACEPTION The Association of Medical Students published, in November, 1939, the results of its questionnaire, sent to 77 of the leading medical schools in the United States, on the teaching of contraception in these schools. An analysis of the replies received showed that (1) there had been a marked increase in the teaching of contraception since the survey in 1932; (2) some schools had special courses in clinical as well as didactic instruction; (3) general student opinion of the training in contraception was that it was grossly inadequate; (4) the majority of schools devoted less than six hours to the subject.

The Association of Medical Students, at its Annual Meeting in December, 1939 adopted a resolution that it "help to promote and increase the teaching of contraception in the medical schools, except in those where such teaching would be contrary to religious doctrine".

HUMAN FERTILITY In January of 1940 the Journal of Contraception, published by the Medical Department of the Birth Control Federation, changed its name to Human Fertility, as more truly expressing its contents. It continues to bring together for scientists and the medical profession, the current developments in the biological and clinical aspects of human reproduction and its control.

FIELD WORK Representatives of the Birth Control Federation of America, Inc. cooperating with various health agencies, extended birth control services to under-privileged mothers in eleven states not yet ready to undertake state-wide programs under their Health Departments. The services were medically supervised and simple contraceptives were advised.

CONFERENCES The Federation cooperated and took part in the Southern Conference on Tomorrow's Children in Atlanta, Georgia, November, 1939 and in the New England Conference for Tomorrow's Children, held in Boston, Massachusetts, July, 1940. The Federation also participated in the National Conference of Social Work; the Texas, Georgia and Kentucky State Medical Association meetings; the American Congress on Obstetrics and Gynecology; and State Conferences on Social Work in Pennsylvania, Tennessee, Georgia and New Jersey.

PUBLIC OPINION Public interest in the movement was evidenced during the year by an increased number of articles favorable to birth control published in leading magazines--both lay and medical. Among these, a pictorial presentation, LIFE (May 6, 1940) entitled "Birth Control: South Carolina uses it for Public Health" created wide interest. A Gallup poll taken during the year showed that 77% of those expressing opinions favored having government health agencies furnish birth control information to married women who wanted it.

U.S. POPULATION POLICIES Wide attention has been given to a report by the Population Committee of the National Economic and Social Planning Association which advocated "Provision for scientific information concerning appropriate methods of contraception for all potential parents is an essential measure for sound population policy." The Committee, composed of leading authorities, stated: "IT is especially necessary as regards qualitative population trends including adequate provisions for child development. It will contribute to the more equitable distribution of population in relation to economic resources. It is also compatible with population maintenance if supplemented by other provisions favorable to voluntary reproduction."

SPECIAL NEGRO PROJECT The Federation, through a special grant of funds, has established a Division of Negro Service, sponsored by a National Advisory Council which includes Negro leadership in all fields. Two special Demonstration Projects have been established, one in Nashville, Tennessee, and one in Berkeley County, South Carolina, to study the effects of medically directed contraception upon the health and welfare of the Negro populations of these sections. The Urban project in Nashville is under the direction of the City Health Officers and the Rural project will be supervised by the Chairman of the Committee on Maternal Welfare of the South Carolina State Medical Association.

LEGAL ACTION The Federal Trade Commission was active during the year against false therapeutic claims for a number of commercial contraceptives. Cease and desist orders were issued against some and suits instituted against others. Such government action is welcomed by the organized movement for birth control, as a step in regulation of the boot-leg traffic in undependable contraceptives.

Of special interest is the activity of the Federal Trade Commission against several concerns attempting to market various devices, slide-rules, etc. advertising and representing the theory that the "safe period" or so-called "Rhythm" method of birth control is a reliable method of birth control. These organizations have filed admissions that according to the weight of reliable medical opinion at present no known method of calculating such periods can be relied upon to indicate accurately periods of sterility and fertility in the menstrual cycle.

LEGAL DECISIONS: CONNECTICUT On March 21, 1940, the Supreme Court of Errors of the State of Connecticut, by a vote of 3 to 2, handed down a decision patterned on that in Massachusetts in 1938. The Connecticut decision upheld the existing statute and ruled that under it, it was illegal for a physician to prescribe, or a patient to use contraceptives, even where definite medical indications existed.
Connecticut is now one of the only two states in the Union where a doctor is forbidden to advise a patient on contraception, and remains the only state where the use of contraceptives is illegal.

IOWA A decision in a suit brought against a druggist in Iowa, in 1937, was handed down by the Supreme Court of that State in 1939. The druggist was accused of violating the law by distributing a pamphlet entitled "Birth Control". The Court ruled him not guilty because the code of laws of the state specifically exempts medical schools, physicians and druggists from the provisions of the Act governing distribution of contraceptive literature or materials.

MASSACHUSETTS While previous Court decisions have declared it illegal for a physician to give contraceptive information under any conditions, the latest decision of the Massachusetts Supreme Court, September 17, by a vote of 3 to 1, reversed a former ruling and declared a pharmacist not guilty in selling certain articles for the prevention of conception because there was no proof they were to be used for the prevention of conception. This decision adds to the existing legal confusion in Massachusetts, making it possible for bootleg traffic in questionable contraceptives to flourish, while legitimate medical contraceptive service remains outlawed. An Initiative Petition, distributed by the Massachusetts Mothers Health Council to amend the statutes involved was filed with over 45,000 signatures, though only 20,000 were legally required.

OPPOSITION Opposition to the Birth Control movement, emanating from the Roman Catholic Church, continued. In Holyoke, Massachusetts, where Mrs. Sanger was scheduled to speak in behalf of the Massachusetts Initiative Petition as part of a state-wide tour of 10 Massachusetts cities, this opposition culminated in pressure brought to bear against directors of the Congregational Church to withdraw permission, previously extended to Mrs. Sanger, to speak from its platform. The same opposition resulted in inability to rent any other public hall. The meeting was finally held in the quarters of the local textile Union.

STATE BIRTH CONTROL FEDERATIONS There are now 33 organized state birth control organizations cooperating with the Birth Control Federation. D. Kenneth Rose became Executive Vice President of the Federation in 1940, and Woodbridge E. Morris, M.D., former Director of the Division of Maternal and Child Health of the Delaware State Board of Health became General Medical Director.
